FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Denaturant tank internal floating roof and inner seals.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

ICM Biofuels, LLC

ICM Biofuels, LLC (ICMB) is submitting its 5-year RMP resubmission under the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68. ICM Biofuels, LLC (ICMB) acquired operational control of the ethanol  production facility at LifeLine Foods, LLC on January 1st, 2014. Original operations were initiated in October 2007. ICMB will review on-site plans on a regular basis and update them when necessary. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES:

ICMB has a commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated in the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel as well as considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the facility. ICMB has emergency response policies in place that are addressed in the facility's Health and Safety (H&S) Plan, the Facility Response Plan (FRP) Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP), and their Emergency Action Plan (EAP). Most of the listed plans have a minimum of annual training requirements in order to keep employees educated on emergency response procedures in place at the facility. Annual training also provides a good time to discuss any situations at the facility the occurred over the previous year that helped the plant gain knowledge on how to better address chemicals or spill practices. New employees are required to undergo training on the plans listed above prior to initiating responsibilities onsite. If job duties warrant, new employees may also be required to read through the plans, as well. ICMB's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, plant personnel will follow the applicable procedures outlined in the SPCC/FRP, Industrial SWPPP, and H&S Plans to respond to, contain, clean up, and properly dispose of the release.

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED:

ICMB is located in St. Joseph, B

uchanan County, Missouri. The facility operates 24 hours per day, 7 days per week for the purpose of manufacturing fuel-grade ethanol from corn. The regulated substance under the RMP program is the Denaturant (also known as natural gasoline which is a flammable mixture). 

WORST CASE AND ALTERNATIVE CASE SCENARIOS:

Worst Case Scenario:
Flammable Mixture (Denaturant): The flammable mixture stored onsite is natural gasoline, typically referred to as denaturant. Natural gasoline is used onsite to denature ethanol prior to shipment offsite. Denaturant is stored in one (1) aboveground steel tank with an internal floating roof located in the facility tank farm. The tank is located in a lined berm with gravel overlay for providing secondary containment. A facility-provided SDS was used to determine RMP applicability. The worst-case scenario used is the release of the entire contents of the denaturant tank, causing a vapor cloud explosion. RMP Comp was used to determine the worst-case distance to endpoint; the model results were 0.7-mile radius. Population data was obtained using Circular Area Profiling System (CAPS) which incorporated 2020 U.S. Census and 2023 American Community Survey (ACS) Data. Public receptor information (i.e. schools, hospitals) was obtained using Google Earth and knowledge of the area. Whitehead Creek would be affected by a worst-case release of denaturant. 

Alternate Case Scenario:
Flammable Mixture (Denaturant): The alternative scenario used for the flammable mixture is the release of natural gasoline due to a tanker truck loadout spill, causing a vapor cloud fire. The endpoint used was an over-pressurization of 1 PSI, a worst-case option. Denaturant deliveries at the facility typically occur during normal business hours with a facility staff member overseeing loadout operations; therefore, a release at the loadout area could be ceased within minutes by manual overrides. The loadout area also has a catchment basin with underground piping to the s

econdary containment of the tank farm. For this scenario, passive and active mitigation was not considered, as the mitigation strategies currently in place would not contain a vapor cloud fire. RMP Comp was used to determine the alternative distance to end point; the model results were 0.1 miles. The Circular Area Profiling System (CAPS) which incorporated 2020 U.S. Census and 2023 American Community Survey (ACS) Data. Public receptor information (i.e. schools, hospitals) was obtained using Google Earth. No environmental receptors would be affected by an alternate release of denaturant. 

The facility qualifies as a Program 3 due to the close proximity of public receptors and being applicable to process safety management (PSM) requirements.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:
General accidental release prevention programs in place at the ICMB facility are described in earlier portions of this Executive Summary and in the Industrial Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan (SWPPP) and Spill Prevention Countermeasure and Control/Facility Response Plans (SPCC/FRP) onsite. As part of recurring training, employees participate in drills and exercises in order to test responsiveness to releases of chemicals onsite. These drills and exercises are evaluated by ICMB management to determine if any additional training or education is required.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:
There have not been any reportable releases of the regulated substance at the ethanol facility within the past 5 years. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION:
ICMB has several safety programs in place at the facility that incorporate emergency response, including a Health and Safety Plan. SPCC and FRP plans have been prepared and implemented in accordance with applicable regulatory standards. FRP regulations require exercises of internal and external notification systems on a semi-annual to annual basis.

Emergency response has also been coordinated with the C

ity of St. Joseph Fire Department and the Buchanan County Emergency Management office so that in the event of an accident or release, immediate response measures can be implemented. ICMBs current policy is one of limited first response and therefore is considered a non-responding facility under 40 CFR 68.90(b).


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:
ICMB will continue to provide annual training programs to employees covering both safety and environmental programs in place at the facility to ensure the continued safety of employees and Contractors. If any additional training is deemed necessary, ICMB will ensure that additional training or education opportunities are presented to the employees in need. There are no planned changes to improve safety at the ICMB facility at this time.
